added_lines: class ProviderDBHelperTestCase(ResourceProviderBaseCase): def _requested_resources(self): """This method returns a dict of the requested resources. The key is the resource class id, the value is requested amount of this resource. """ resources = { fields.ResourceClass.STANDARD.index(fields.ResourceClass.VCPU): 1, fields.ResourceClass.STANDARD.index( fields.ResourceClass.MEMORY_MB): 64, fields.ResourceClass.STANDARD.index( fields.ResourceClass.DISK_GB): 1500, } return resources def test_get_provider_with_any_resource(self): # Create two compute node providers with VCPU, RAM and local disk. # cn1 has the vcpu, memory and disk. But without enough disk space. # cn2 only has the vcpu and disk. cn1_uuid = uuidsentinel.cn1 cn1 = rp_obj.ResourceProvider( self.ctx, name='cn1', uuid=cn1_uuid, ) cn1.create() cn2_uuid = uuidsentinel.cn2 cn2 = rp_obj.ResourceProvider( self.ctx, name='cn2', uuid=cn2_uuid, ) cn2.create() for cn in (cn1, cn2): inv_list = [] vcpu = rp_obj.Inventory( resource_provider=cn, resource_class=fields.ResourceClass.VCPU, total=24, reserved=0, min_unit=1, max_unit=24, step_size=1, allocation_ratio=16.0, ) # cn2 doesn't have memory reosurce if cn.uuid == cn1_uuid: memory_mb = rp_obj.Inventory( resource_provider=cn, resource_class=fields.ResourceClass.MEMORY_MB, total=32768, reserved=0, min_unit=64, max_unit=32768, step_size=64, allocation_ratio=1.5, ) inv_list.append(memory_mb) # cn1 doesn't have enough disk if cn.uuid == cn1_uuid: disk_gb = rp_obj.Inventory( resource_provider=cn, resource_class=fields.ResourceClass.DISK_GB, total=1000, reserved=100, min_unit=10, max_unit=1000, step_size=10, allocation_ratio=1.0, ) else: disk_gb = rp_obj.Inventory( resource_provider=cn, resource_class=fields.ResourceClass.DISK_GB, total=2000, reserved=100, min_unit=10, max_unit=2000, step_size=10, allocation_ratio=1.0, ) inv_list.extend([vcpu, disk_gb]) disk_gb.obj_set_defaults() inv_list = rp_obj.InventoryList(objects=inv_list) cn.set_inventory(inv_list) res = rp_obj._get_providers_with_any_resource(self.ctx, self._requested_resources()) self.assertEqual(set([cn1.id, cn2.id]), set(res.keys())) res_list = [] for rp_id in res.keys(): for resource in res[rp_id]: res_list.append(resource) expected_res = sorted([ [0, 24, 0], [0, 24, 0], [1, 32768, 0], [2, 2000, 0] ]) self.assertEqual(expected_res, sorted(res_list))

commit_message:
Add Puppet build jobs to check and gate pipelines

In order to ensure a successful build, all puppet modules will
attempt to be built as part of puppet-release-jobs template
to ensure that it is successfully released.

Change-Id: I5fde7e7f5747f50d4703161be0ab2f797840b630
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-zuul-jobs refs/changes/95/519495/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: check: jobs: - build-openstack-puppet-tarball gate: jobs: - build-openstack-puppet-tarball

subject: Avoid running Puppet module build job for no reason
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-11-13 22:47:54.000000000', 'files': ['zuul.d/jobs.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-zuul-jobs/commit/ba51fbee4b577b9750274c28a1c545b578a656a5', 'message': 'Avoid running Puppet module build job for no reason

The puppet module build job mainly depends on any metadata.json
changes which generally affect version bumps.  There is no need
to run the job if we will not be building the module.

Change-Id: Iff411b4eb2bcc2c403608461d5ef313c01df9009
'}]
commit_message:
Avoid running Puppet module build job for no reason

The puppet module build job mainly depends on any metadata.json
changes which generally affect version bumps.  There is no need
to run the job if we will not be building the module.

Change-Id: Iff411b4eb2bcc2c403608461d5ef313c01df9009
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-zuul-jobs refs/changes/94/519494/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: files: ^metadata.json$

subject: Remove httpd logs directory mounting from swift
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-11-14 07:00:55.000000000', 'files': ['docker/services/swift-proxy.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/c731d88058e1a2bf45a42c3efd6afffc6e45adf5', 'message': "Remove httpd logs directory mounting from swift

Swift doesn't run over httpd. So there's no need to mount the httpd log

Change-Id: Ife5a4c7ab0ffe49fd56ce911e4f7b808bfe875c9
"}]
commit_message:
Remove httpd logs directory mounting from swift

Swift doesn't run over httpd. So there's no need to mount the httpd log
directory.

Change-Id: Ife5a4c7ab0ffe49fd56ce911e4f7b808bfe875c9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/56/519556/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Switch Puppet tarball job to use Zuul role

We created a role which can build a Puppet module so let's leverage
that instead of duplicating the code.

Depends-On: I45761c2d111640733ddec8b4c08066655b6944e2
Change-Id: Ib4d1bf79b0468a44b08c738b7db3fa65b6e47767
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-zuul-jobs refs/changes/91/519491/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: roles: - build-puppet-module
deleted_lines: tasks: - name: Build puppet module command: puppet module build . args: chdir: "{{ zuul.project.src_dir }}"

subject: Make eventlet hub use a monotonic clock
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-09-14 04:23:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/masakari/commit/92dffc134f2a73ce65a35070b2ce872c1ca8cc80', 'message': 'Make eventlet hub use a monotonic clock

If system time is adjusted first forward and then backward while a
masakari-engine service is running, then the periodic tasks stops
for the duration of time the system clock was adjusted backward.

This was supposed to be fixed by the following patch to oslo.service
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/286838/ , but the order of imports
in unit tests and production code is different, so nova services
end up starting with the default eventlet hub, that does not use a
monotonic clock and, thus, is affected by changes of system time.

Testing the change done in the patch is problematic, as it's a
subject of imports order and is not reproduced in functional or
unit tests (oslo_service is always imported earlier than eventlet
hub is initialized, so it just does "the right thing").
The alternative is to make an assertion when services start.

This patch is the copy of below nova commit:
a7505ee648b22f5827117bcc1192b5654c29cf9c

Change-Id: I9d917b3151d9cdf7340a173b5baf98def63c76cd
Closes-Bug: #1510234

commit_message:
Make eventlet hub use a monotonic clock

If system time is adjusted first forward and then backward while a
masakari-engine service is running, then the periodic tasks stops
for the duration of time the system clock was adjusted backward.

This was supposed to be fixed by the following patch to oslo.service
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/286838/ , but the order of imports
in unit tests and production code is different, so masakari services
end up starting with the default eventlet hub, that does not use a
monotonic clock and, thus, is affected by changes of system time.

Testing the change done in the patch is problematic, as it's a
subject of imports order and is not reproduced in functional or
unit tests (oslo_service is always imported earlier than eventlet
hub is initialized, so it just does "the right thing").
The alternative is to make an assertion when services start.

Co-Authored-By: Roman Podoliaka <rpodolyaka@mirantis.com>
Closes-Bug: #1510234
Change-Id: I9d917b3151d9cdf7340a173b5baf98def63c76cd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/masakari refs/changes/39/503939/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def assert_eventlet_uses_monotonic_clock(): import eventlet.hubs as hubs import monotonic hub = hubs.get_hub() if hub.clock is not monotonic.monotonic: raise RuntimeError( 'eventlet hub is not using a monotonic clock - ' 'periodic tasks will be affected by drifts of system time.')

commit_message:
Consume horizon in-tree django variant jobs

The legacy jobs legacy-horizon-tox-py27dj1* needs to be clean up,
so it is not a good idea to consume them in horizon plugin jobs.
It prevents from pushing them away.
This commit tries to py27dj1* zuulv3 jobs defined in the horizon repo.

Needed-By: I23a95b36e73bb444f94683c801eda11fb1430aa8
Change-Id: I040b35a4830423dce6fa4279882a01b8e88ad5f9

commit_message:
[WIP][POC] Host plugin information from os-vif

This patch adds the host plugin information in the port binding
profile dict and transfered to Neutron during the port update.
In this phase, Nova updates the port with the host id (port binding).

This object (os_vif.objects.host_info.HostInfo) provides Neutron the
available VIF information of the system.

Needed patches:
- os-vif: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/441590/

Change-Id: I892918a8bad5b9dc343c379db68f3eab81cb9d5e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/41/499941/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import os_vif profile = {} # DEBUG(ralonsoh) profile['host_info'] = os_vif.host_info().obj_to_primitive() port_req_body['port'][BINDING_PROFILE] = profile # https://review.openstack.org/#/c/493082/ needed to print correctly # the HostInfo object. # LOG.debug("Host plugin information: %s" % profile['host_info'])

commit_message:
Intel Fortville Dynamic Device Personalization (DDP)

Within Intel Fortville version 6, a new feature was introduced: Fortville
Dynamic Device Personalization (DDP) [1]_ to program an analyzer or parser
via AdminQ. A profile can be used to update FVL configuration tables via
MMIO configuration space; this profile is not microcode or firmware itself.

This spec proposes to add a new method to read from the libvirt driver the
DDP loaded profile in a network device. This new parameter will be added
to `LibvirtConfigNodeDevicePciCap` to extend the PCI NIC information.

The present feature plans to use the existing API, amending the reported
profile string to the NIC capabilities string list. Users will request
capabilities and a specific profile using the same string list in the
Neutron binding profile.

blueprint intel-fortville-ddp

Change-Id: I182ee5d5293204d0fd57188d7918bd6e14975d5d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/01/503001/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================================================== Intel Fortville Dynamic Device Personalization (DDP) ==================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/intel-fortville-ddp Within Intel Fortville version 6, a new feature was introduced: Fortville Dynamic Device Personalization (DDP) [1]_ to program analyzer/parser via AdminQ A profile can be used to update FVL configuration tables via MMIO configuration space, not microcode or firmware itself. This new hardware feature allows to offload certain type of workloads. Currently only one profile is publicly available, MPLS (Multiprotocol Label Switching), but new ones will become available in the closer future. Problem description =================== Currently Nova doesn't have the ability to track or read this specific network interface parameter. Use cases --------- * A service, running in a virtual machine, is going to use intensively MPLS tagged frames traffic. The user wants to spawn this virtual machine in a host with MPLS traffic offload in order to save CPU resources Proposed change =============== This spec proposes to add a new method to read from the livbirt driver the DDP loaded profile in a network device (currently only supported by Intel Fortville [2]_ 6 network interface). A new parameter will be added to `LibvirtConfigNodeDevicePciCap` class, called `profile`. This parameter will contain a string with the name of the profile loaded in the network interface, the ID and the version. This information will be stored in a XML along with these attributes. Every publicly available DDP profile name will be added to `os-traits` in order to track and offer them as standard traits. Each profile name is unique and invariant, enough to describe a profile. The suggested place to locate these profile names is ``os_traits.hw.ni.offload`` In blueprint `Enable SR-IOV NIC offload feature discovery` [3]_ (feature still in progress), `Placement API` was upgraded to also filter by virtual functions (`nova.objects.fields.ResourceClass.SRIOV_NET_VF` type). Users can define specific hardware capabilities to a port by defining them in the port binding profile:: $ openstack port create --binding-profile '{"capabilities": ["RX", "TSO"]}' --network private port1 Those capabilities are defined in `os-traits`; any capability not present in `os-vif` will be omitted. The present feature plans to use the existing API, amending the reported profile string to the NIC capabilities string list. Users will request capabilities and a specific profile using the same string list in the Neutron binding profile:: $ openstack port create --binding-profile '{"capabilities": ["RX", "TSO", "MPLS"]}' --network private port1 Because of the limited hardware support for this feature, if the virt driver doesn't support the NIC profile reading or the hardware doesn't provide this feature, the parameter `profile` stored in `LibvirtConfigNodeDevicePciCap` won't be populated. NIC feature information ----------------------- With the modifications implemented, libvirt will provide an additional parameter in the list of capabilities for a NIC device. Using the command line utility we can retrieve the following information :: $ virsh nodedev-dumpxml net_ens785_68_05_ca_34_83_60 <device> <name>net_ens785_68_05_ca_34_83_60</name> <path>/sys/devices/pci0000:00/0000:00:02.0/0000:02:00.0/net/ens785</path> <parent>pci_0000_02_00_0</parent> <capability type='net'> <interface>ens785</interface> <address>68:05:ca:34:83:60</address> <link state='down'/> <feature name='rx'/> <feature name='tx'/> <feature name='sg'/> <feature name='tso'/> <feature name='gso'/> <feature name='gro'/> <profile name='mpls' id='123456760' version='1.23.22'/> ^-- example of NIC profile <capability type='80203'/> </capability> </device> Alternatives ------------ Instead of adding a new parameter to `LibvirtConfigNodeDevicePciCap`, the DDP profile parameter, which is a string, could be added to the `features` list. `features` is a list of offload features already implemented [4]_ (patch from [3]_), containing a set of available hardware offload properties. Adding the string value of the NIC profile to `features` can simplify the code Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Rodolfo Alonso Hernandez (ralonsoh) <rodolfo.alonso.hernandez@intel.com> Other contributors: Sean K Mooney (sean-k-mooney) <sean.k.mooney@intel.com> Work Items ---------- * Implement a libvirt plugin, based on DPDK library, to make it aware of this new parameter in the network interface. * Add a new trait per DDP profile. Because currently there is only one avaiable, a trait called MPLS (under os_traits.hw.nic.offload) will be created. * A method to read from the hardware, using libvirt, the loaded DDP profile. There are no plans yet to support other virt drivers. Dependencies ============ * Placement API [5]_ * SR-IOV NIC features enabled [3]_ Testing ======= * Add unit tests to check libvirt XML parser accepts correctly this new parameter if exists; in other case, should be omitted. * Once Intel FVL CI is up and running, add tempest test to check this feature. Documentation Impact ==================== * Amend user Placement API documentation to include this new trait and how it's read. References ========== _[1] http://dpdk-test-plans.readthedocs.io/en/latest/ddp_mpls_test_plan.html _[2] https://www.intel.com/content/dam/www/public/us/en/documents/datasheets/xl710-10-40-controller-datasheet.pdf _[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/q/project:openstack/nova+branch:master+topic:bp/enable-sriov-nic-features _[4] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/444415 _[5] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/user/placement.html History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Queens - Introduced

commit_message:
Cleanup of OpenDaylight on ./clean.sh

Currently, clean up(clean.sh( does not stop opendaylight
therefore some directory can not be deleted because they are
being used by OpenDaylight, which result in some data still
pending and ODL running. This patch makes sure to stop opendaylight
and clean it's data.

Change-Id: I919b62a91e400586c01c6acb87d66cac1f936fa6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl refs/changes/66/519266/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: stop_opendaylight cleanup_opendaylight

commit_message:
Fix AodhAlarmTest to use gnocchi

This changes the test to use AodhGnocchiAggregationByMetricsAlarm
and add measures using gnocchi api.

Change-Id: I0b2fe154b93d9882b703e95a0b09f139697ceb9a
Closes-Bug: #1727637
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/91/515391/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import datetime from heat.common import timeutils # create metric metric = self.metric_client.metric.create({ 'name': 'my_metric', 'archive_policy_name': 'high', }) # create the stack parameters = {'metric_id': metric['id']} stack_identifier = self.stack_create(template=self.template, parameters=parameters) measures = [{'timestamp': timeutils.isotime(datetime.datetime.now()), 'value': 100}, {'timestamp': timeutils.isotime( datetime.datetime.now() + datetime.timedelta( minutes=1)), 'value': 100}] # send measures(should cause the alarm to fire) self.metric_client.metric.add_measures(metric['id'], measures) # confirm we get a scaleup.
deleted_lines: # 1. create the stack stack_identifier = self.stack_create(template=self.template) # 2. send ceilometer a metric (should cause the alarm to fire) sample = {} sample['counter_type'] = 'gauge' sample['counter_name'] = 'test_meter' sample['counter_volume'] = 1 sample['counter_unit'] = 'count' sample['resource_metadata'] = {'metering.stack_id': stack_identifier.split('/')[-1]} sample['resource_id'] = 'shouldnt_matter' self.metering_client.samples.create(**sample) # 3. confirm we get a scaleup.

commit_message:
Apply QoS policy on network:router_gateway

All router ports (internal and external) used to be excluded from QoS
policies applied on network. This patch excludes only internal router
ports from network QoS policies.
This allows cloud administrators to set an egress QoS policy to a
public/external network and have the QoS policy applied on all external
router ports (DVR or not). To the tenant this is also egress traffic so
no confusion compared to QoS policies applied to VM ports.

DocImpact

Update networking-guide/config-qos, User workflow section:
- Replace "Network owned ports" with "Internal network owned ports"

Change-Id: I2428c2466f41a022196576f4b14526752543da7a
Closes-Bug: #1659265
Related-Bug: #1486039

commit_message:
Add periodic job to build wheels for openSUSE 42.3

We will need an infra-root to provision a opensuse423-based slave
'wheel-mirror-opensuse-423-amd64'.

Change-Id: I196f025dbf1a9ac297946b8165620676645f7210

commit_message:
Install hacking first and let it pull in right linter versions

hacking pulls in the right versions of flake8 and flake8 does
depend on the right versions of mccabe, flake8, pycodestyle by itself,
so install that one first and remove the explicit listing of those
dependencies.

Change-Id: I99ad1c1c31c4ba9e0c7e3ed692e650a9b4aba13b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/74/515374/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

nested directories

commit_message:
Use service_type and service_name of nova_catalog_admin_info

Masakari has never used service_type and service_name of
nova_catalog_admin_info. However, these can be specified
when masakari creates a novalient object.
This patch modified so that masakari uses these.

Change-Id: I7fdd3b47230bea004a9129234c88d20d611814bf
Closes-Bug: #1724764
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/masakari refs/changes/99/513299/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: service_type=service_type, service_name=service_name,

" msgid "" "# The maximum overflow size of the pool used by SQLAlchemy. When the number " "of checked-out connections reaches the size set in sql_pool_size, additional " "connections will be returned up to this limit. It follows then that the " "total number of simultaneous connections the pool will allow is " "sql_pool_size + sql_pool_max_overflow. Can be set to -1 to indicate no " "overflow limit, so no limit will be placed on the total number of concurrent " "connections. Comment out to allow SQLAlchemy to select the default." msgstr "" "# The maximum overflow size of the pool used by SQLAlchemy. When the number " "of checked-out connections reaches the size set in sql_pool_size, additional " "connections will be returned up to this limit. Can be set to -1 to indicate no " "overflow limit, so no limit will be placed on the total number of concurrent " "connections. subject: Remove unused IronicObjectIndirectionAPI from ironic-api
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-11-02 21:20:29.000000000', 'files': ['ironic/tests/base.py', 'ironic/cmd/api.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/7b09d3e8dc3306d59940e7d8c92321fa2b2eb273', 'message': "Remove unused IronicObjectIndirectionAPI from ironic-api

Many moons ago, we thought that we would implement rolling upgrades
using a similar model to nova. This included adding an instance
of an IronicObjectIndirectionAPI to the ironic-api service. What
it was meant to do was for ironic-api to invoke it if it received
an IronicObject that it didn't know what to do with (because it
didn't recognize that object's version). That API would have
invoked the conductor service, asking it to generate a version
of that object which ironic-api would understood.

To use this mechanism, the assumption is that the conductor is
the gateway to the DB.

This mechanism doesn't work for ironic for a few reasons:
- ironic API reads (and occasionally) writes directly to the database.
  We don't want to change it to get access to the DB via the
  conductor all the time, since for e.g. we don't want to slow down
  the conductor
- Nova's rolling upgrade process is to initially take down all their
  conductor services (which handles their DB interactions) at the
  same time,  while their other services are still running. Unless
  ironic changes to have a similar model, we cannot take down all
  the conductor services at the same time if ironic is to provide
  services during a rolling upgrade.

Thus, this patch removes the unused IronicObjectIndirectionAPI from
the ironic-api service. Note that the IronicObjectIndrectionAPI
class itself (in ironic/objects/indirection.py) was left, in case
things ever change in the future. (And because removing that would
involve touching most, if not all, of the files in the objects/
subdirectory.)

Change-Id: I1aa264a8619105939968c0b8128b358badf00210
Closes-Bug: #1586320
"}]
commit_message:
Remove unused IronicObjectIndirectionAPI from ironic-api

Many moons ago, we thought that we would implement rolling upgrades
using a similar model to nova. This included adding an instance
of an IronicObjectIndirectionAPI to the ironic-api service. What
it was meant to do was for ironic-api to invoke it if it received
an IronicObject that it didn't know what to do with (because it
didn't recognize that object's version). That API would have
invoked the conductor service, asking it to generate a version
of that object which ironic-api would understood.

To use this mechanism, the assumption is that the conductor is
the gateway to the DB.

This mechanism doesn't work for ironic for a few reasons:
- ironic API reads (and occasionally) writes directly to the database.
  We don't want to change it to get access to the DB via the
  conductor all the time, since for e.g. we don't want to slow down
  the conductor
- Nova's rolling upgrade process is to initially take down all their
  conductor services (which handles their DB interactions) at the
  same time,  while their other services are still running. Unless
  ironic changes to have a similar model, we cannot take down all
  the conductor services at the same time if ironic is to provide
  services during a rolling upgrade.

Thus, this patch removes the unused IronicObjectIndirectionAPI from
the ironic-api service. Note that the IronicObjectIndrectionAPI
class itself (in ironic/objects/indirection.py) was left, in case
things ever change in the future. (And because removing that would
involve touching most, if not all, of the files in the objects/
subdirectory.)

Change-Id: I1aa264a8619105939968c0b8128b358badf00210
Closes-Bug: #1586320
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/39/517439/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: from ironic.objects import base from ironic.objects import indirection # Enable object backporting via the conductor base.IronicObject.indirection_api = ( indirection.IronicObjectIndirectionAPI())

commit_message:
Correct log message when removing a security group

When a security group is removed from a port nova
incorrectly logs this as a security group addition

Change-Id: If525313c63c4553abe8bea6f2bfaf75431ed18ea
Closes-bug: 1731889

commit_message:
Add proposals to index

- move all approved proposals to `/proposals`
- use the same folder structure as previous releases for `pike`

So that we can preview the proposal on CI build

Change-Id: I63472cdfaac89cc81db77ee1df6d4be2cd8d216a
Signed-off-by: Yujun Zhang <zhang.yujunz@zte.com.cn>

commit_message:
Initializing logging for set ovs hostconfig command

networking_odl/cmd/set_ovs_hostconfigs.py script does not generate
logs in file or on console. These logs can be helpful for debugging
purpose. This patch enable creation of log file for this script.

Change-Id: Icc1fda55522c1ab47f5d9f07104d189fe8e7ba0a
Closes-bug: #1717520
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl refs/changes/53/505053/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron.common import config config.setup_logging()

commit_message:
devstack: add error check to _wget and _xpath

Sometimes sporadic error happens due to external network issue when
getting ODL distribution. Add more error checks to each diagnose
and exit early.

Change-Id: I697edf1e29a62dba69c5762a2a851817d2a48b87
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl refs/changes/85/518785/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: local ALLOW_MISSING=${4:-False} if [[ ! -r $MAVENMETAFILE && "$ALLOW_MISSING" != "True" ]]; then echo "$MAVENMETAFILE doesn't exist. Please try with OFFLINE=False to download $URL" exit 1 fi if [[ ! -r $MAVENMETAFILE && "$ALLOW_MISSING" != "True" ]]; then echo "can't download $URL. Please check intenet connection, site availability or directory permision to create file $MAVENMETAFILE" exit 1 fi if [[ -z "$result" ]]; then echo "xpath can't find matching xpath $XPATH" 1>&2 cat $MAVENMETAFILE 1>&2 exit 1 fi _wget $MAVENMETAFILE ${_NEXUSPATH}/${BUNDLEVERSION}/maven-metadata.xml $OFFLINE True

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-11-07 03:45:58.000000000', 'files': ['ironicclient/tests/unit/common/test_filecache.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-ironicclient/commit/5eac09e66b4d4b2a25b6b57d8f97608f3a306156', 'message': 'Mock filecache.CACHE in unit tests

This mocks the global filecache.CACHE in unit tests that modify the

For example, ..unit.test_client.ClientTest.test_loader_arguments_token
has failed with  ...

Change-Id: I84b9c6699c98d1fa642247808b6ddea4fae1e8d0
'}]
commit_message:
Mock filecache.CACHE in unit tests

This mocks the global filecache.CACHE in unit tests that modify the
value. This is to avoid errors when other unit tests are running
at the same time, that use that same variable.

For example, ..unit.test_client.ClientTest.test_loader_arguments_token
has failed with  ...
    File "ironicclient/common/filecache.py", line 103, in retrieve_data
     data = _get_cache().get(key, expiration_time=expiry)
  AttributeError: 'int' object has no attribute 'get'

Change-Id: I84b9c6699c98d1fa642247808b6ddea4fae1e8d0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-ironicclient refs/changes/12/518212/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch.object(filecache, 'CACHE', None) self.assertEqual(cache_val, filecache.CACHE) @mock.patch.object(filecache, 'CACHE', None) self.assertEqual(cache_val, filecache.CACHE) @mock.patch.object(filecache, 'CACHE', None) self.assertEqual(cache_val, filecache.CACHE) @mock.patch.object(filecache, 'CACHE', 5552368) self.assertEqual(5552368, filecache._get_cache()) self.assertEqual(5552368, filecache.CACHE)
deleted_lines: filecache.CACHE = None filecache.CACHE = None filecache.CACHE = None cache_val = 5552368 filecache.CACHE = cache_val self.assertEqual(cache_val, filecache._get_cache())

commit_message:
Add missing library 'oslo.context 'in requirement.txt

Masakari uses oslo.context library for creating RequestContext
but it is not listed as a requirement in requirement.txt.

This patch adds oslo.context in requirement.txt.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: Ibbd2fabf30ac8fca289e205180ce12ba8b1999b3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/masakari refs/changes/36/516536/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Fix devstack installation of masakari
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-10-31 03:53:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/masakari/commit/d3fa556ecf89da0cb51ea6fb1d2aecdff81a18cb', 'message': "Fix devstack installation of masakari

Recently a commit: 188173a8072b143a28779b875af617ac7f35a92d got
merged into masakari which replaces a rpc method 'get_transport'
with 'get_rpc_transport'. The 'get_rpc_transport' expects the
oslo.messaging config option 'transport_url' [1] to be present in
the [DEFAULT] section of masakari.conf. The current masakari devstack
script doesn't add 'transport_url' in masakari.conf which results
into failure of devstack installation of masakari.

This patch fixes this issue by using an inbuilt devstack function
'iniset_rpc_backend' to add the 'transport_url' config option in
masakari.conf.

[1] * https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/master/oslo_messaging/transport.py#L44
    * https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/master/oslo_messaging/transport.py#L201

Closes-Bug: #1728544
Change-Id: I75da054c6669aa90dd96c3ede3ae98de74275de2
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-11-14 04:31:47.000000000', 'files': ['devstack/plugin.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/masakari/commit/57bbe7deada89ad35da885451315f216d2f53919', 'message': "Fix devstack installation of masakari

Recently a commit: 188173a8072b143a28779b875af617ac7f35a92d got
merged into masakari which replaces a rpc method 'get_transport'
with 'get_rpc_transport'. The 'get_rpc_transport' expects the
oslo.messaging config option 'transport_url' [1] to be present in
the [DEFAULT] section of masakari.conf. The current masakari devstack
script doesn't add 'transport_url' in masakari.conf which results
into failure of devstack installation of masakari.

This patch fixes this issue by using an inbuilt devstack function
'iniset_rpc_backend' to add the 'transport_url' config option in
masakari.conf.

[1] * https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/master/oslo_messaging/transport.py#L44
    * https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/master/oslo_messaging/transport.py#L201

Closes-Bug: #1728544
Change-Id: I75da054c6669aa90dd96c3ede3ae98de74275de2

commit_message:
Fix devstack installation of masakari

Recently a commit: 188173a8072b143a28779b875af617ac7f35a92d got
merged into masakari which replaces a rpc method 'get_transport'
with 'get_rpc_transport'. The 'get_rpc_transport' expects the
oslo.messaging config option 'transport_url' [1] to be present in
the [DEFAULT] section of masakari.conf. The current masakari devstack
script doesn't add 'transport_url' in masakari.conf which results
into failure of devstack installation of masakari.

This patch fixes this issue by using an inbuilt devstack function
'iniset_rpc_backend' to add the 'transport_url' config option in
masakari.conf.

[1] * https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/master/oslo_messaging/transport.py#L44
    * https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/master/oslo_messaging/transport.py#L201

Closes-Bug: #1728544
Change-Id: I75da054c6669aa90dd96c3ede3ae98de74275de2

added_lines: iniset_rpc_backend masakari $MASAKARI_CONF DEFAULT

commit_message:
Modify unit testcases according to oslo.context

oslo.context>=2.19.1 outputs 'project' key in context's to_dict
function.
The value of 'project' key is same as 'project_id' key.

So this patch modifies unit testcases according to the above changs.

And, this patch adds oslo.context to requirements.txt.
oslo.context had been installed related to oslo.versioned object
until now.
But, it is better to describe it explicitly because Masakari uses
the library.

Change-Id: Ibebed8a4e5bfd49f192b1cf876b7538f9c057f97

commit_message:
Move and update test_resize_volume_backed_server_confirm

There is a bug in nova where the libvirt driver incorrectly removes
the local guest files for the hypervisor from shared storage because
it does not realize the instance is volume-backed. Nova runs an NFS
CI job in the experimental queue but it's not failing on resize
tests because they aren't volume-backed, so to recreate the failure
and make sure we don't regress the fix, this test is added. Nova
also runs a Ceph job which applies here too.

This moves the existing scenario test to be a compute API test. The
test ID is maintained in case people are blacklisting it, but the
slow tag is dropped because it's not a particularly slow test and
if the slow tag is applied, it won't actually be run in the jobs
that we care about testing this, e.g. NFS and Ceph jobs.

The additional wrinkle of getting the console log after the resize
is what shows the failure when the bug is not fixed, so that's added
here.

Depends-On: I29fac80d08baf64bf69e54cf673e55123174de2a

Change-Id: Id7de5186b2ea0ff7af86d9950c69203914498d88
Related-Bug: #1728603
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/96/516396/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @decorators.idempotent_id('04d613fe-74a5-425f-a69e-e444f9e767d8') @testtools.skipUnless(CONF.compute_feature_enabled.resize, 'Resize not available.') @utils.services('volume') def test_resize_volume_backed_server_confirm(self): # We have to create a new server that is volume-backed since the one # from setUp is not volume-backed. validation_resources = self.get_class_validation_resources( self.os_primary) server = self.create_test_server( validatable=True, volume_backed=True, validation_resources=validation_resources, wait_until='ACTIVE') self.server_id = server['id'] # The class variable is unfortunate... self._test_resize_server_confirm(stop=False)

commit_message:
Drop Makefile

We don't use 'make' command in our development process and
they are rarely maintained. It looks better to drop them.

Change-Id: Ic4fe0fa79f9a1749162d5e4109a2dc86e156afca
Related-Bug: #1483917

commit_message:
Revert "Migrate oneview driver to use python-hpOneView"

Reverting these changes because python-hpOneView does not provide HTTPS
secure connection with custom CAcert and could cause a possible security issue.

This reverts commit 0ed998dfc81109f3a09100cb3b128e692be92e20.

Change-Id: I8b7f767c2bda8f3d57881ef61466e5d73c898970

subject: Ignores ssl configuration option added in local.conf
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-01-02 04:11:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/53155c3337577997724cbae41a01c5958f0bf6c9', 'message': 'Ignores ssl configuration option added in local.conf

If you add SSL_ENABLED_SERVICES option in local.conf, then it
is completely overridden by fixed set of services
"key,nova,cinder,glance,s-proxy,neutron" as defined in stack.sh.
The reason being stack.sh first reads SSL_ENABLED_SERVICES config
option from local.conf and then overrides it by shell variable
SSL_ENABLED_SERVICES="key,nova,cinder,glance,s-proxy,neutron".

Moved declaration of SSL_ENABLED_SERVICES before sourcing local.conf
file so that, if user wants to configure SSL for other services
then he/she can add it in local.conf like;

SSL_ENABLED_SERVICES+=<service_name>

Change-Id: I8676d50b60994d30ba998cd758c6921df49f4dbc
Closes-Bug: #1653203

commit_message:
Ignores ssl configuration option added in local.conf

If you add SSL_ENABLED_SERVICES option in local.conf, then it
is completely overridden by fixed set of services
"key,nova,cinder,glance,s-proxy,neutron" as defined in stack.sh.
The reason being stack.sh first reads SSL_ENABLED_SERVICES config
option from local.conf and then overrides it by shell variable
SSL_ENABLED_SERVICES="key,nova,cinder,glance,s-proxy,neutron".

Appended SSL_ENABLED_SERVICES from local.conf file to already defined
sets of services so that, if user wants to configure SSL for other
services then he/she can add it in local.conf like;

SSL_ENABLED_SERVICES=<service_name>

Change-Id: I8676d50b60994d30ba998cd758c6921df49f4dbc
Closes-Bug: #1653203

commit_message:
Add virtio-scsi controller when attaching volume

Add support to use virtio-scsi controller when attaching
cinder volume to the instance.

APIImpact
Implements: add-virtio-scsi-attach-volumes

Change-Id: I613abb235b2a35a3ca946261ff55af78100c74dc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/23/451723/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================ Add virtio-scsi controller when attaching volume ================================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/add-virtio-scsi-attach-volumes Allow users to specify the use of VirtIO SCSI for KVM instances while attaching the volumes. Problem description =================== VirtIO SCSI is a new para-virtualized SCSI controller device for KVM instances. It has been designed to replace virtio-blk to improve scalability. Presently, virtio-scsi bus is supported when booting instance from volume if you have created a volume from a image containing specialized libvirt driver options metadata properties "hw_disk_bus" and "hw_scsi_model". This feature was added back in Icehouse by BP [1]. However, there is no provision to specify disk_bus and disk_model parameters in request body of the os-volume_attachments api. Use Cases --------- * Improve scalability - virtual machines can connect to more storage devices. * Support SCSI commands - virtual machines can use SCSI related feature with attached volume, e.g. Windows Storage Spaces [2], some cluster software etc. Proposed change =============== The compute api 'attach_volume' method already has disk_bus parameter, which is available on the compute side but it's default value is set to None. The disk_bus parameter is not available in the request body of the os-volume_attachments RESTful API. We propose to modify 'os-volume_attachments' Restful api to pass 'disk_bus' and 'disk_model' in the request body.:: { "volumeAttachment": { "volumeId": "a26887c6-c47b-4654-abb5-dfadf7d3f803", "disk_bus": "scsi", "disk_model": "virtio-scsi" } } To ensure 'disk_bus' and 'disk_model' information is available at the nova-compute side, we will need to modify compute api, compute rpc and virt driver 'attach_volume' interface. We plan to use these parameters in the libvirt driver. At libvirt side, when attaching a disk for bus type 'scsi', an additional SCSI controller is added by libvirt automatically which by default uses 'Lsi' model. <controller type='scsi'/> In order to use 'virtio-scsi' model when disk_bus is 'scsi', we will need to add this model to the controller explicity before attaching actual disks. One controller of type 'scsi' will be added per instance. <controller type='scsi' model='virtio-scsi'/> Alternatives ------------ To avoid making changes to the os-volume_attachments RESTful API, user can add 'disk_bus' and 'disk_model' as metadata of a volume and we can use this metadata information to add scsi controller at the libvirt side. Still, it will require changes to the virt 'attach_volume' interface to pass 'disk_model' information. Data model impact ----------------- To use 'disk_model', a new column will be added to the 'block_device_mapping' database table. This column will be of string type with 255 length and nullable. The default value will be null. REST API impact --------------- os-volume_attachments ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ User will be able to specify 'disk_bus' and 'disk_model' as an input to 'volume-attach' api as a part of request body, which will lead to changes in json schema. A microversion bump is required for the same. Example Attach a volume to an instance: JSON request:: { "volumeAttachment": { "volumeId": "a26887c6-c47b-4654-abb5-dfadf7d3f803", "disk_bus": "scsi", "disk_model": "virtio-scsi" } } JSON response body example:: { "volumeAttachment": { "device": "/dev/sda", "id": "a26887c6-c47b-4654-abb5-dfadf7d3f803", "serverId": "0c92f3f6-c253-4c9b-bd43-e880a8d2eb0a", "volumeId": "a26887c6-c47b-4654-abb5-dfadf7d3f803", "disk_bus": "scsi", "disk_model": "virtio-scsi" } } Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Abhishek Kekane Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Migration script to add 'disk_model' column to 'block_device_mapping' * Modify schema to validate 'disk_bus' and 'disk_model' * Modify model and BlockDeviceMapping object to support 'disk_model' * Modify RPC call reserve_block_device_name to support 'disk_model' * Add controller with 'virtio-scsi' model at the compute side * Unit tests for coverage Dependencies ============ Nobe Testing ======= * Need to write functional tests Documentation Impact ==================== We need to add good developer documentation to explain how disk_bus and disk_model options can be used. References ========== * [1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/libvirt-virtio-scsi-driver * [2] https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh831739(v=ws.11).aspx * https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Virtio-scsi-for-bdm History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Pike - Introduced

subject: VolumeManager: Check available capacity before creating resources
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-02-23 21:30:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/41bdbae15bbbd4a238c72aba70b2570e82cbebcd', 'message': "VolumeManager: Check available capacity before creating resources

For some resources, due to their inheritance of the 'host' attribute
from the source where they are asked to create from, the 'CREATE'
request doesn't go through Cinder scheduler, thus missing the chance to
check if the storage backend still have capacity.  Such resources are
snapshots, volume clones and potentially volume replication clones.  In
some cases, current implementation is fine because those new resource
would end up being in 'error' state if backend is out of capacity, but
in the case where thin-provisioning is desired and the backend has
max over-subscription ratio set, this might cause backend to serve more
than it should if the backend doesn't enforce simliar checks.

This change adds a capacity check in Volume Manager or its corresponding
taskflow before manager calls the backend driver to create the resource.

An alternative solution is the simply passing all create request to
scheduler even for those resource has known 'host'.  It'll be
implemented in separate change for comparison.

Change-Id: I0e0f10562f45eea1014d3bf6bd4d355dbfd967df
Closes-bug: #1537166

commit_message:
VolumeManager: Check available capacity before creating resources

For some resources, due to their inheritance of the 'host' attribute
from the source where they are asked to create from, the 'CREATE'
request doesn't go through Cinder scheduler, thus missing the chance to
check if the storage backend still have capacity.  Such resources are
snapshots, volume clones and potentially volume replication clones.  In
some cases, current implementation is fine because those new resource
would end up being in 'error' state if backend is out of capacity, but
in the case where thin-provisioning is desired and the backend has
max over-subscription ratio set, this might cause backend to serve more
than it should if the backend doesn't enforce simliar checks.

This change adds a capacity check in Volume Manager or its corresponding
taskflow before manager calls the backend driver to create the resource.

An alternative solution is the simply passing all create request to
scheduler even for those resource has known 'host'.  It'll be
implemented in separate change for comparison.

Change-Id: I0e0f10562f45eea1014d3bf6bd4d355dbfd967df
Closes-bug: #1537166
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/77/437677/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from cinder.scheduler import host_manager from cinder.scheduler.filters import capacity_filter def check_capacity(self, resource): """Check if current backend's capacity is sufficient.""" # get latest backend stats volume_stats = self._construct_volume_stats() size = 0 # (zhiteng) For now, this function only supports Volume and Snapshot # other resource support can be added in later change as needed. if isinstance(resource, objects.Volume): size = resource.size elif isinstance(resource, objects.Snapshot): size = resource.volume_size else: LOG.debug("Not volume or snapshot, API doesn't support " "this type yet: %(resource)s", {'resource', resource}) # Set size of resource to large enough so it'd fail filtering size = float(inf) # prepare input for CapacityFilter state = host_manager.PoolState(self.host, volume_stats) request = {'size': size } cap_filter = capacity_filter.CapacityFilter() return cap_filter.host_passes(state, request) sufficient_cap = self.check_capacity(snapshot) if not sufficient_cap: msg = "Insufficient capacity on storage." raise exception.VolumeDriverException(msg) volume_stats = self._construct_volume_stats() # queue it to be sent to the Schedulers. self.update_service_capabilities(volume_stats) def _construct_volume_stats(self): volume_status = self.driver.get_volume_stats(refresh=True) if self.extra_capabilities: volume_stats.update(self.extra_capabilities) if volume_stats: # Append volume stats with 'allocated_capacity_gb' self._append_volume_stats(volume_stats) # Append filter and goodness function if needed volume_stats = ( self._append_filter_goodness_functions(volume_stats)) return volume_status
deleted_lines: volume_stats = self.driver.get_volume_stats(refresh=True) if self.extra_capabilities: volume_stats.update(self.extra_capabilities) if volume_stats: # Append volume stats with 'allocated_capacity_gb' self._append_volume_stats(volume_stats) # Append filter and goodness function if needed volume_stats = ( self._append_filter_goodness_functions(volume_stats)) # queue it to be sent to the Schedulers. self.update_service_capabilities(volume_stats)

Remove legacy jobs from ansible-role-diskimage-builder

These are no longer needed as we are moving to native zuulv3 jobs.

commit_message:
Preserve preexisting ports on container delete

This patch allow the existing port to be unbound from the
container on container delete whereupon the port will still
exist but not be associated with the container.

Change-Id: Id047ccf8b7189a0fd149ac88f3776f2573c319cd
Closes-Bug: #1704016

enable_elasticsearch is in group_vars and is enabled automatically
if skydive is enabled.

commit_message:
specs for support-volume-binds

Change-Id: Ie610573205112008ed83f4562000545fff9f2418
Implements: blueprint support-volume-binds
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zun refs/changes/62/517562/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================ Local Volume Integration ============================ Related Launchpad Blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/zun/+spec/support-volume-binds Zun has introduced an option for users to bind-mount Cinder volumes to containers. But users can't mount local volume to containers, this function is like the option '-v' of docker run/create: $ docker run -v /host/path:/container/path <image> The above command will bind-mount the directory with path '/host/path' into path '/container/path' inside the container. Problem description =================== Some special application containers need use the files/directory in localhost for initializing process or getting a large amount of data. For example: $ docker run -it --volume=/dev:/dev --volume=/proc:/proc:ro sysdig/sysdig So zun should implement the option, and this option should work well with the cinder volume together. Proposed change =============== This spec proposes the following changes. 1. It's unsafe to mount the host directory into the container, so only admin can bind-mount local file system to container. 2. We leverage the --mount option for cinder volume bindmount. It is better to reuse this option for bind-mounting local file system. For example: $ zun run --mount voltype=<local|cinder>,source=...,destination=... <image> 3. Zun introduces a config (called 'forbidden_volume.conf'). Operators can tune this config to restrict the path for bind-mounting. 4. The administrator would be aware that a special container should be scheduled on which nodes. Users may combine --mount and --label options to create a container. Workflow ============= The typical workflow to create a container with a Local volume will be as following: 1. A user calls Zun APIs to create a container with a local volume:: $ zun run --mount voltype=local,source=/proc,destination=/proc \ --label <key=value> centos 2. After receiving this request, Zun will check if the mount info has local volumes. Then it will check the user has administrator permissions operation. 3. Zun will create a item for local volume, and store in the volume_mapping table. 4. Zun will choose a node by the option --label, and check the local volume whether in the volume lists in forbidden_volume.conf. 5. Zun will calls Docker API to create a container and use the option "-v". $ docker run -d -v /proc:/proc centos Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- Deployers need to deploy a Fuxi and Cinder. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Feng Shengqin Other contributors: Dependencies ============ Testing ======= Each patch will have unit tests, and Tempest functional tests covered. Documentation Impact ==================== A set of documentation for this new feature will be required. References ========== [1] https://docker-py.readthedocs.io/en/stable/containers.html#container-objects.

Add driver support for delete image

This patch adds driver support for delete image, including glance
and docker.

subject: A python tool to orchestrate kolla kubernetes.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-07-27 18:23:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-kubernetes/commit/ecd4bc6107b330ce759502b188d8ec2e4abe2b57', 'message': "Python tool to bring up Kubernetes and OpenStack

This tool provides a method to deploy OpenStack on a Kubernetes Cluster using
Kolla and Kolla-Kubernetes on bare metal servers or virtual machines. Virtual
machines supported are Ubuntu and Centos.

Versions supported are 4.x (Ocata) and 5.x.

I started developing it as I worked on the project and the Deployment Guide.

In no way is this supposed to be an official production method.

It is however very simple to use (ko.py eth0 eth1), and I have verified it on
Centos and Ubuntu and Ocata and Pike.

It comes with a 'demo' mode that attempts to explain each step to the user.

It comes with lots of switches to play with different versions of all the tools
used.

Change-Id: I85858d06efcbda686bcfa177d41e6f002f98cb03
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-07-28 13:33:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-kubernetes/commit/d98f38137010092ab88cfad12ada97ae95aa246a', 'message': "Moved ko.py to orchestration/tools

verified it on Centos and Ubuntu and Ocata and Pike.

It comes with a 'demo' mode that attempts to explain each step
to the user.

It comes with lots of switches to play with different versions
of all the tools used.

Change-Id: I85858d06efcbda686bcfa177d41e6f002f98cb03
